title.value: Static graph approximations of dynamic contact networks for epidemic forecasting
title.justification: The title clearly states the focus of the paper which is on creating static graph approximations from dynamic networks in order to forecast epidemics.
title.quote: Static graph approximations of dynamic contact networks for epidemic forecasting

extractions.description: This paper addresses the challenge of forecasting epidemic spread by proposing novel methods to approximate future contact networks from past dynamic graphs. The methods, DegMST and EdgeMST, aim to preserve the sparsity of real-world contact networks and provide better approximations than traditional full static graphs, leading to more accurate epidemic modeling.

type.justification: The paper involves empirical experiments on real-world datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods (DegMST and EdgeMST) for epidemic forecasting.
type.quote: We conduct experiments on seven real-world dynamic contact networks of different sizes with up to 9.5 million edges.

name.justification: The paper's core focus is on modeling the spread of infectious diseases using graph-based approaches, specifically epidemic forecasting.
name.quote: Epidemic modeling is essential in understanding the spread of infectious diseases like COVID-19 and devising effective intervention strategies to control them.

name.justification: The paper deeply integrates graph theoretical concepts such as temporal graphs, static approximations, and minimum spanning trees into epidemic modeling.
name.quote: We propose two novel static network approximation methods, DegMST and EdgeMST, designed to preserve the sparsity of real world contact networks.

name.justification: The study simulates epidemic spread using different graph structures to evaluate the performance of their proposed methods.
name.quote: We demonstrate that our EdgeMST algorithm is highly effective for epidemic forecasting as a proxy for future contact network.

name.justification: COVID-19 serves as one of the primary context or application areas for the epidemic models discussed in the paper.
name.quote: Recently, spread of COVID-19 on dynamic networks has been used for different applications with interesting results.

name.justification: EdgeMST is one of the proposed models designed to approximate static graphs from dynamic networks for better epidemic forecasting.
name.quote: We introduce two novel conversion methods from a dynamic graph to a static one, namely EdgeMST and DegMST, for the purpose of epidemic modeling.

is_contributed.justification: EdgeMST is a novel contribution presented by the authors of the paper for improving epidemic forecasting.
is_contributed.quote: We introduce two novel conversion methods from a dynamic graph to a static one, namely EdgeMST and DegMST, for the purpose of epidemic modeling.

is_executed.justification: The paper does not provide any indication that EdgeMST was executed on specific hardware like a GPU or CPU.

is_compared.justification: EdgeMST is compared numerically against other static graph methods in terms of approximating epidemic spread dynamics.
is_compared.quote: We demonstrate that our EdgeMST algorithm is highly effective for epidemic forecasting as a proxy for future contact network.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper title provided for EdgeMST as it is a new contribution by the authors.

name.justification: DegMST is another proposed model aimed at creating static network approximations from dynamic graphs for epidemic forecasting.
name.quote: We introduce two novel conversion methods from a dynamic graph to a static one, namely EdgeMST and DegMST, for the purpose of epidemic modeling.

is_contributed.justification: DegMST is a novel contribution the authors have presented in their work on epidemic forecasting.
is_contributed.quote: We introduce two novel conversion methods from a dynamic graph to a static one, namely EdgeMST and DegMST, for the purpose of epidemic modeling.

is_executed.justification: There's no information in the paper that specifies DegMST was executed on particular hardware like a GPU or CPU.

is_compared.justification: DegMST is numerically compared with other methods, including the full static approach, in terms of disease spread approximation.
is_compared.quote: Our analysis show that our models more closely resemble the network characteristics of the dynamic graph compared to the full static ones.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper title for DegMST as it is a new model introduced by the authors.

name.justification: The Copenhagen dataset is explicitly mentioned as being used to demonstrate the proposed models' capability to forecast disease spread.
name.quote: Figure 1 illustrates the main findings of this paper, where we compare the disease spreading dynamics of the full static, DegMST, EdgeMST, and the dynamic graphs using a real-world contact network-the Copenhagen dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Interaction data from the Copenhagen networks study
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is referenced with a specific work title that details its design and data collection approach.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Copenhagen dataset was gathered from close contacts between university students using Bluetooth devices.

name.justification: The paper describes the usage of the Workplace dataset to test the proposed static graph models.
name.quote: Workplace, Lyon school and High school datasets were collected as part of the Sociopattern project using radio-frequency identification sensors.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references SocioPatterns datasets as the source for the Workplace dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Workplace, Lyon school and High school datasets were collected as part of the Sociopattern project using radio-frequency identification sensors.

name.justification: The Lyon School dataset was used in the experiments to evaluate the performance of new static graph approximation methods.
name.quote: Workplace, Lyon school and High school datasets were collected as part of the Sociopattern project using radio-frequency identification sensors.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Lyon School dataset is part of the SocioPatterns datasets mentioned in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Workplace, Lyon school and High school datasets were collected as part of the Sociopattern project using radio-frequency identification sensors.

name.justification: This dataset is used in the paper to assess the effectiveness of the proposed graph approximation methods.
name.quote: Workplace, Lyon school and High school datasets were collected as part of the Sociopattern project using radio-frequency identification sensors.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The High School dataset is referenced as part of the SocioPatterns datasets, which the paper cites.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Workplace, Lyon school and High school datasets were collected as part of the Sociopattern project using radio-frequency identification sensors.

name.justification: The paper makes use of the Conference dataset to test the hypothesis regarding static graph approximations.
name.quote: Conference, Workplace, Lyon school and High school datasets were collected as part of the Sociopattern project using radio-frequency identification sensors.

referenced_paper_title.justification: As with the other datasets, this is part of the referenced SocioPatterns datasets cited in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Conference, Workplace, Lyon school and High school datasets were collected as part of the Sociopattern project using radio-frequency identification sensors.

name.justification: Wi-Fi dataset is used to assess the performance of the proposed static network approximation methods on large-scale networks.
name.quote: Wi-Fi dataset is extracted from connections to Wi-Fi hot-Spots in Montreal.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is referenced with a specific title related to its collection methodology.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Lenczner, M. & Hoen, A. G. Crawdad ilesansfil/wifidog.

name.justification: SafeGraph dataset is incorporated in the analysis to validate the proposed models on real-world contact networks.
name.quote: SafeGraph dataset was collected by monitoring the mobility of individuals using mobile signals, and reports the weekly number of visits from Canadian Dissemination Areas (DA) to different Point of interests (POI).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is identified under SafeGraph Weekly Patterns in the references section.
